title: 103_s1899
content:
There are no paragraphs provided in the prev_chunk, so I will summarize the curr_chunk directly.

Summarized chunk:
"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." The Augusta Canal National Landmark in Georgia is listed on the National Historic Register and designated as a significant resource. It boasts excellent water quality, historic landscapes, mill structures, and parks. Several national historic districts and landmarks are connected by the Augusta Canal Area. The Augusta Canal Area connects historic landmarks like Stallings Island and Meadow Garden, showcasing rural landscapes and cultural heritage. The canal played a crucial role in transforming the area from agrarian to industrial, representing the development of the cotton textile industry in the South. Numerous significant sites related to American Revolution, Civil War, Native Americans, and Colonial history are also present in the area. The Augusta Canal area includes significant sites related to American Revolution, Civil War, Native Americans, Colonial Americans, African Americans, Chinese Americans, and Irish Americans. Despite efforts from various entities, the cultural, historical, natural, and recreational resources in the area have not reached their full potential and are considered threatened by the Secretary of the Interior. Many local, regional, and State agencies, businesses, and private citizens are eager for Federal Government assistance in preserving the area. Many local, regional, and State agencies, businesses, and private citizens are eager to work together to preserve and enhance the resources of the Augusta Canal National Historic Landmark. The purpose of this Act is to establish a cooperative management framework for the Augusta Canal National Heritage Area in Georgia to preserve its significant features while promoting economic development. The Augusta Canal National Heritage Area is established in Georgia and includes lands in Georgia and South Carolina known as the Augusta Canal. The boundaries are outlined in the Augusta Canal Master Plan. The Secretary of the Interior will publish a detailed description and map of the boundaries. Additionally, an Augusta Canal Commission will be established. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed from various entities including the Augusta Canal Authority, the mayor of Augusta, Georgia, the Georgia congressional delegation, the Governor of Georgia, and the Governor of South Carolina. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed from various entities including the Augusta Canal Authority, the mayor of Augusta, Georgia, the Georgia congressional delegation, the Governor of Georgia, and the Governor of South Carolina. The Commission shall elect a chairman from among its members, and vacancies will be filled in the manner of the original appointment. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed from various entities. The Commission shall elect a chairman from among its members, and vacancies will be filled in the manner of the original appointment. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Augusta Canal Commission must prepare a management plan for the Heritage Area within a year of this Act's enactment. The plan should integrate Federal, State, and local plans, including the Augusta Canal Master Plan, to protect and enhance the area's cultural, natural, scenic, and recreational resources. The Secretary can offer technical and financial assistance for the plan's preparation, and approval must be given within 180 days of submission. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the management plan for the Heritage Area within 180 days of submission. Approval criteria include local support, economic compatibility, partnership potential, and protection of private property rights. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the management plan for the Heritage Area within 180 days of submission. If disapproved, the Augusta Canal Commission must revise and resubmit the plan with recommendations for revision. The Augusta Canal Commission must revise and resubmit the management plan until approved by the Secretary. Upon approval, the Secretary will work with the Commission to implement the plan through cooperative agreements with various entities. The Augusta Canal Commission, along with the State of Georgia and other political subdivisions, will work to implement the management plan. Economic development in the area will be encouraged to align with the goals of the Augusta Canal Master Plan. SEC. 6. ENVIRONMENTAL STANDARDS. This Act does not impose stricter regulations on the Heritage Area than those in place before its establishment. No Federal agency can introduce more stringent regulations solely due to the Heritage Area's creation. SEC. 7. DUTIES OF OTHER FEDERAL ENTITIES. SEC. 7. Duties of other Federal entities include consulting, cooperating, and coordinating activities with the Secretary and Augusta Canal Commission to avoid adverse effects on the Heritage Area. SEC. 8. Authorization of appropriations for carrying out this Act.
